intro: Lappula redowskii f. cupulata, commonly known as the cupulate lappula, is a variant of the lappula plant characterized by its distinctive cup-like structures on its stems. This plant belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is native to certain regions of Europe. Its botanical features include small, greenish-yellow flowers that are arranged in clusters, and it typically grows in dry, sandy soils. The f. cupulata form is distinguished by the presence of specialized leaf structures that form a cup-like shape, providing protection to the growing shoot. This unique morphological trait is an adaptation to its arid habitat, aiding in water retention and reducing desiccation.
